results.title: Behaviour therapy: an introduction (TEFC)
results.brief_description: This film describes and explains three models for learning: operant; classical and observational. Demonstrates the application of each model in therapeutic settings involving behaviour therapists and clients. No other credits available.

results.title: Behaviour patterns at one year
results.creator_credit: Arnold Gesell and Yale Clinic of Child Development
results.brief_description: Portrays the behaviour patterns of a normal infant fifty-two weeks of age. The baby’s manipulation and other reactions to one, two, three, and ten cubes are interpreted and discussed by the narrator. Continues with the study of other test situations involving a cup and a spoon, cup and cubes, pellet, pellet and bottle, ball, ring and string, paper and crayon, a performance box, and a form board.

results.title: Behaviour modification: teaching language to psychotic children (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: O-Ivor Lovaas, Robert Aller and Appleton-Century-Crofts
results.brief_description: Shows typical speech patterns of autistic and schizophrenic children, and discusses correction of these before learning begins. Demonstrates instruction methods in imitation of sounds, labelling of objects, discrimination between alternatives, recall of experiences, and development of some spontaneity.

results.title: Beginnings of conscience
results.brief_description: A driver obeys traffic signs even when there is no one in sight because he has a conscience, instilled since childhood by his daily life at home, school, and work. The socialization process is analysed in terms of the life of an “average” boy. Shows influence of parental approval or disapproval, peer acceptance or rejection, and forms of discipline in various social situations. In a nutshell, this film implores the “educational aspect of punishment.” It explains that without socialisation, and without the sanctions used to achieve it, there would be no basis for moral order in human society.

results.title: Beginning french: intonation
results.brief_description: Compares the characteristic patterns of French and English intonation in a number of every-day phrases and sentences. Analysing French intonation, a class of students learn to listen for basic patterns and their variations, and how to reproduce the characteristic “music” of French speech. Stresses the importance of practice in listening as well as in speaking. No other credits available.

results.title: Mozart: Symphony No. 41 in C Major, Menuetto Allegretto (3rd Movement)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Music in Motion Series”.
A series of abstrzct scenes of nature in a variety of rhythms, moods and tempos give added significance to the music in Mozart’s Minuet from the “Jupiter” Symphony.

results.title: Allegro molto from the symphony No.5 in E flat by Jean Sibelius
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Music in Motion”.
Scenes of the granitic hardness and glacial sparkle of Finland describe part of the Fifth Symphony of Sibelius. Snow-capped mountains and trees reflected in deep blue lakes, falling snow in a dense evergreen forest, sunny snow-banks of a glacier reflect the composer’s changing moods from strong unrelenting harmonies to soft tremolos and pizzicato passages. (A study guide is available with this film). From the “Music in motion” series.

results.title: Moussorgsky: 'Pictures at an exhibition'
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Music in Motion”.
Scenes of the flower gardens at Paris’ Louvre and Tuileries Park, children playing, fluffy chicks running about, the bustling market place at Limoges and the Paris Catacombs are shown to express part of Moussorgsky’s composition “Pictures at an Exhibition”. The composer wrote the music to pay homage to paintings by his friend Victor Hartmann.
